issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Pneumatic.raisePressure(pressure: double): void, but the reference solution defines Pneumatic.raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) (and the implementing classes override an int parameter). This is a parameter-type mismatch for a core interface method and will confuse students about which type to use and produce signature mismatches if tests or templates expect the other type.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the parameter type consistent across all artifacts. Either change the UML and problem text to declare raisePressure taking an int (e.g. raisePressure(pressureIncrease: int): void) to match the solution, or change the solution (and implementing classes) to use double as declared in the UML (void raisePressure(double pressure)). Apply the chosen type uniformly to Pneumatic and all implementing classes.

issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction: the UML lists raisePressure(pressure: double) but the Remarks explicitly reference raisePressure(int pressureIncrease). This conflicts within the specification itself and will leave students uncertain which signature is intended.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the contradiction in the problem statement: either update the UML and all references to use double consistently, or update the UML to use int so it matches the wording in the Remarks. Ensure the example method signature and the textual remarks reference the same parameter type and name.

issues.description: The Pneumatic.raisePressure method is inconsistently specified between the problem statement UML and the solution code (and the problem text): the UML declares raisePressure(pressure: double) while the remarks in the problem text and the solution implementation use an int parameter named pressureIncrease (raisePressure(int pressureIncrease)). This mismatch affects both the parameter type (double vs int) and the parameter name (pressure vs pressureIncrease). Students may be unsure which signature to implement and could implement the wrong method signature, causing compilation/test failures and unnecessary confusion.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the raisePressure signature across all artifacts. Preferred quick fix: update the UML in problem_statement.md to declare raisePressure(pressureIncrease: int): void (and replace 'pressure' with 'pressureIncrease') so it matches the problem text and the solution implementation. Alternatively, if double precision is required, change the solution interface and all implementing classes to use double pressure and update the problem text accordingly. Ensure the same parameter name and type are used everywhere to avoid student confusion.
